```
instructor/function_calls.py OpenAISchema import json import logging from functools import wraps from typing import Annotated, Any, Optional, TypeVar, cast from docstring_parser import parse from openai.types.chat import ChatCompletion from pydantic import (     BaseModel,     ConfigDict,     Field,     TypeAdapter,     create_model, ) from instructor.exceptions import IncompleteOutputException from instructor.mode import Mode from instructor.utils import (     classproperty,     extract_json_from_codeblock,     map_to_gemini_function_schema, ) T = TypeVar("T") logger = logging.getLogger("instructor") model_config = ConfigDict(ignored_types=(classproperty,))     @classmethod
    def parse_vertexai_json(
        cls: type[BaseModel],
        completion: ChatCompletion,
        validation_context: Optional[dict[str, Any]] = None,
        strict: Optional[bool] = None,
    ) -> BaseModel:
        return cls.model_validate_json(
            completion.text, context=validation_context, strict=strict
        )
```

It seems the code defines a function parse_vertexai_json as a classmethod, which takes a Pydantic BaseModel subclass, a ChatCompletion object from OpenAI, optional validation context and strict flag, and returns a BaseModel instance by validating JSON from completion.text.

The code also imports utilities for extracting JSON from code blocks, mapping to Gemini function schema, etc. It sets up a logger and a model_config that ignores classproperty types.

Thus the business logic: It provides a method to parse JSON responses from Vertex AI (or OpenAI) chat completions into Pydantic models, with optional validation context and strict mode.
